results.title: [Len Moncur Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
The Len Moncur Home Movie Collection is a collection of amateur films made on 8mm film in the 1950s and 1960s.

This animated film, titled ‘Storm at the 20th’, is a comedy about a group of beleaguered golf ball people, often wearing golf tee hats and with pipe cleaner limbs, who come together to protest against injury from golfers. They decide to take evasive action including using feathers to fly out of the way of golf sticks and a self-destructing do-it-yourself glider kit.

There are details such as the terrible injuries inflicted by golfers and one of the organisers drinking non-stop from what looks like a whiskey bottle.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:07:00 title cards ‘Storm at the 20th’ and ‘Animation by Len Moncur’
00:00:10:00 golf ball people are rushing around a busy street
00:00:18:00 a sign ‘Protest Meeting - Every Brand - Even repaints – Something must be done!’
00:00:26:00 sign ‘Trades Hall 20th Hole Branch’
00:00:29:00 wonderful miniature and detailed vehicles pass by including a tram from which many golf ball people alight
00:00:38:00 close-up of ‘Before it happens towing service’ tow truck
00:00:43:00 golf ball mechanics fix a broken down vehicle
00:00:50:00 an injured golf ball mechanic is taken away by stretcher and ambulance
00:01:16:00 the protest meeting proceeds with the manifesto stating that golf ball people are being treated badly by golfers
00:01:25:00 one of the organisers drinking strong spirits followed by several examples of gruesome golf ball injuries
00:02:35:00 baby golf ball people in a bassinette
00:02:48:00 the golf ball people learn evasive tactics on the golf course
00:04:33:00 boxes labelled ‘Do it yourself Glider Kit’ followed by a demonstration of how the glider assists the golf ball person avoid being hit by a golfer by flying through the air and then self-destructing once the golf ball person shields in a bush
00:05:09:00 the golf ball people squash into their sporty car and after travelling down the road, pop themselves into their boxes
00:05:24:00 title ‘The End’

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 8]
results.headline_credit: Australia, Fiji, New Caledonia and New Zealand, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film shows a cruise from Sydney Harbour to possibly New Caledonia, Fiji and New Zealand, including scenic views, time with friends’ son and off the cruise ship.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:34:00 leaving Sydney Harbour in cruise ship; views of the Opera House and the Harbour
00:01:36:00 views from lookout wth friends, looking over a small city
00:04:27:00 a day trip from cruise to island, maybe New Caledonia, due to circular style of grass hut
00:05:26:00 ring volleyball game on cruise ship
00:06:43:00 views from cruise ship coming into port at Nadi, Fiji
00:08:26:00 filmmaker’s wife Evelyn with local family, and swimming at the beach
00:10:08:00 cruise ship coming into port, marching band farewells/welcomes passengers
00:11:50:00 Rainbow Springs sign, Rotorua, NZ
00:12:06:00 trout farm at Rainbow Springs Nature Park
00:13:42:00 hot springs in New Zealand
0014:27:00 cruise ship coming back into Sydney harbour, views of cliffs surrounding Sydney Harbour

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.headline_credit: Australia and Papua New Guinea, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film is shot in New Guinea and features the filmmaker’s family and friends, locals, people gathering in vast numbers for celebrations in various traditional dress, Chinese dragon display, scenic views, and road safety issues. Most likely filmed around Goroka, as the filmmaker lived mainly in Goroka.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:00:00 opens with footage shot around the filmmaker’s home; we see a sign with his name, Alex Sinclair, out the front of the white house; family and friends around the garden
00:03:23:00 car wreck being towed away and off the road
00:04:50:00 filmmaker and friends have a picnic on top of a hill. Local kids come to watch and pose for the camera.
00:05:55:00 along a river, feeding fish with friends, and a nearby wild bird sanctuary or zoo
00:07:29:00 Missionary Aviation Fellowship aircraft at airfield
00:08:32:00 stunning mountain views
00:10:14:00 lunch with friends at a restaurant near the bay
00:11:24:00 traditional Chinese Dragon dance and fire crackers along a town street
00:12:35:00 Lions Club road safety campaign displaying cars salvaged from crashes
00:13:46:00 celebrations of people in traditional dress from various districts; remarkable head dresses and masks made from mud or clay, alongside those made from feathers and woven materials, dancing, building hut demonstrations
00:14:36:00 more truck accidents; local kids come to see, then dance and entertain the filmmaker and friends
00:15:46:00 more stunning views of mountains
00:16:14:00 more ceremonial gatherings of various people and audiences

results.title: [Nicoll Family Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
Filmmaker Alexander Nicoll made a range of home movies in Australia from the 1930s to the 1960s. The family film collection was donated to ACMI by Alexander’s son Mac.

This reel captures the excitement of the 1956 Olympics in Melbourne with footage of the decorated buildings in the city featuring the department stores of the era – Foy’s, Buckley’s, Myer, Coles Store and Woolworths. Also included is a family wedding and scenes from the beach.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 views of Melbourne’s decorated department stores – Foy’s, Buckley’s, Myer, Coles Store (as it was named then) and Woolworths
00:01:42:00 family wedding scenes
00:02:54:00 wedding shots at the church including 1950s fashion style
00:03:24:00 family members at the beach show off the style of the day – striped towels, and a range of clothes from trousers to bathers with ‘shirring’ and sundresses

results.title: 100 Pages
results.brief_description: ‘100 Pages’ is a project based upon the theme of North Sydney Girls High School’s Centenary. This project used the School’s identity and history as inspiration for artmaking. Through the artmaking, students are celebrating the school’s identity in the present and past community; isolating individual events, subjects and objects as inspiration. The title of the unit, ‘100 Pages’, comes from the initial idea of 100 animations, for 100 years of history. This project has been developed for the Stage 5 elective, Year 10 Photography and Digital Media class (PDM), which comprises 12 students from North Sydney Girls High School.

results.title: [Nicoll Family Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
Filmmaker Alexander Nicoll made a range of home movies in Australia from the 1930s to the 1960s. The family film collection was donated to ACMI by Alexendar’s son Mac.

This reel features the family at Carrum beach in Victoria. We see some great examples of swimsuits at the time as well as women’s suits and hats and a boy in a kilt. The reel ends with scenes around the Shrine of Remembrance in Melbourne.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 begins with two women and a boy walking through sandy bush to the beach, smiling at the camera
00:00:36:00 father and son atop an upturned boat on the beach, posing and waving for the camera
00:00:35:00 the boy running along the sand toward the camera
00:00:45:00 woman running from a bathing box along the sand, stopping briefly for the camera where we see her wearing a knotted headscarf, typical of the day, as a bathing cap
00:01:30:00 man drying himself post swim
00:01:35:00 example of a halter neck one piece women’s swimwear of the era
00:01:57:00 scenes of bushland before we see people picking blackberries
00:02:40:00 a child stares at the camera
00:02:45:00 two older women wearing suits and felt hats typical of the era, sitting on a car running board, one knitting
00:03:00:00 the family group are playing for the camera before playing in a park
00:03:35:00 group picnic around the cars so the running boards can be used as seats
00:04:40:00 riverside stroll with terrier dog
00:05:07:00 backyard cricket practice
00:06:00:00 young boy in kilt and cap with mother in stylish suit and shoes of the day
00:06:11:00 scenes around the Shrine of Remembrance in Melbourne
results.description:
Filmmaker Alexander Nicoll made a range of home movies in Australia from the 1930s to the 1960s. The family film collection was donated to ACMI by Alexendar’s son Mac.

This reel features the family at Carrum beach in Victoria. We see some great examples of swimsuits at the time as well as women’s suits and hats and a boy in a kilt. The reel ends with scenes around the Shrine of Remembrance in Melbourne.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 begins with two women and a boy walking through sandy bush to the beach, smiling at the camera
00:00:36:00 father and son atop an upturned boat on the beach, posing and waving for the camera
00:00:35:00 the boy running along the sand toward the camera
00:00:45:00 woman running from a bathing box along the sand, stopping briefly for the camera where we see her wearing a knotted headscarf, typical of the day, as a bathing cap
00:01:30:00 man drying himself post swim
00:01:35:00 example of a halter neck one piece women’s swimwear of the era
00:01:57:00 scenes of bushland before we see people picking blackberries
00:02:40:00 a child stares at the camera
00:02:45:00 two older women wearing suits and felt hats typical of the era, sitting on a car running board, one knitting
00:03:00:00 the family group are playing for the camera before playing in a park
00:03:35:00 group picnic around the cars so the running boards can be used as seats
00:04:40:00 riverside stroll with terrier dog
00:05:07:00 backyard cricket practice
00:06:00:00 young boy in kilt and cap with mother in stylish suit and shoes of the day
00:06:11:00 scenes around the Shrine of Remembrance in Melbourne

results.title: [Nicoll Family Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
Filmmaker Alexander Nicoll made a range of home movies in Australia from the 1930s to the 1960s. The family film collection was donated to ACMI by Alexendar’s son Mac.

This reel is of the filmmaker’s daughter Jean and her visitor, Toddy. Toddy is in military uniform when he rounds a corner of a house to chat happily to Jean, with their dog and pet birds. While on leave from the RAF, Toddy was billeted to the family home in Essendon during his time in Melbourne.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:01:00 Toddy enters the frame from a side path of to visit Jean at her home
00:00:12:00 Jean leans out the window to chat to Toddy
00:00:16:00 Toddy enthusiastically welcomes a dog into the scene
00:00:20:00 Jean presents two pet birds on her arm for the camera

results.title: [Nicoll Family Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Alexander (Alex) Nicoll (1898–1968) grew up in Princes Hill in Melbourne.

As a young man, and after working in various capacities, Alex met wealthy business owner Arthur Thomas who assisted him into business running an import agency at Tasmania House in Flinders Lane. Alex would enjoy a lifelong involvement with Melbourne’s ‘rag trade’ (clothing business) in Flinders Lane, including serving for some years as the President of the Victorian Softgoods Association.

In the 1930s Alex inherited an Agfa 16mm camera, projector and collapsible screen from Arthur Thomas who had been a keen photographer, and over the 1940s and 1950s would capture wonderful moments around Melbourne such as the celebrations for the 1956 Olympics and visits to the beaches of Port Phillip Bay.

After Alexander died, his son Mac continued the family filming enthusiasm in the 1960s and 1970s. Around 2005, the Nicoll family decided to donate most of their collection of films to ACMI.

This reel captures a military parade likely to be sometime in the 1940s down Alexandra Parade, Moonee Ponds and some garden views.

Selected highlight list:

00:00:00:05 a crowd lines the street (most likely Mt Alexander Road near Moonee Ponds Town Hall, the family lived in Essendon)
00:00:00:28 soldiers parade down the street before a crowd of onlookers
00:00:00:51 parade passes a dais on which people stand, one in a mayoral robe and chain of office
00:01:12:00 military trucks and equipment can be seen in the parade
00:01:38:00 soldiers relaxing on the lawn with members of the crowd after the parade

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 25]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures a trip along the ‘Great Ocean Road’ in Victoria. The Great Ocean Road is an Australian National Heritage listed 243 kilometres stretch of road along the south-eastern coast of Victoria between Torquay and Allansford near Warrnambool. The film features many scenes of the ocean, coastal walks, rock formations such as the Twelve Apostles, and seaside towns.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:12:00 title cards ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘The Ocean Road’, ‘Filmed by WHC’
00:01:01:00 woman walking down a path from the lighthouse at Airey’s Inlet
00:01:14:00 the historic ‘Great Ocean Road’ sign over the highway
00:01:27:00 sign for ‘Cinema Point lookout’ with vintage car in foreground
00:05:06:00 the Twelve Apostles
00:09:20:00 two people at a lookout
00:12:00:00 woman lying on the ground with a camera
00:14:50:00 boats in a bay
00:16:31:00 a small harbour
00:17:38:00 a bluestone church, likely St John’s in Port Fairy
00:017:57:00 the Yambuk Inn in Port Fairy
00:19:42:00 an emu running down the road
00:19:57:00 two women comparing sticks for walking
00:23:42:00 a jetty by a river
00:24:40:00 sunset over the water
00:25:01:00 title card ‘The End’

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 24]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures a group walking trip by members of the ‘Walkabouters’ club to the Grampians (Gariwerd) in Victoria. It features the making of a ‘pit oven’ style barbeque and showcases the walking to be had by visitors through the many ravines and paths but also the grandeur of the sweeping views from what can seem like perilous pinnacles and lookouts.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title cards ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘The Dreaming Place’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:00:38:00 views of the Grampians range off in the distance
00:00:56:00 driving through a small township
00:02:51:00 creating a ‘pit oven’ by setting a fire in a deep hole in the ground
00:02:59:00 stones are thrown into the flames and then covered with pieces of terracotta tiles on which meat in aluminium foil is placed for cooking
00:03:38:00 the pit is covered with a piece of metal, hessian bags, stones and dirt
00:04:15:00 a woman climber is helped to the top of some rocks
00:06:10:00 cars driving along a dirt road in the bush
00:06:44:00 an example of the the beautiful rock of the Grampians
00:07:07:00 sign for ‘Forest Commision of Victoria’ ‘Camp of the Emu’s Foot’
00:07:15:00 Indigenous art on rock walls
00:09:48:00 a still river which runs under a wooden walk bridge among tall reeds
00:10:19:00 a fenced off shallow cavern possibly with Indigenous drawings on the rock
00:10:35:00 views of Indigenous drawings up close
00:11:07:00 driving through the bush
00:11:54:00 grey patchy granite rock of the Grampians
00:12:29:00 a lone walker stands on top of a high peak
00:15:25:00 walking through the bush
00:17:00:00 groups of kangaroos and emus
00:18:23:00 climbing a steep ravine
00:20:19:00 sitting on a precipice overlooking the dramatic scenery below
00:20:43:00 a large body of water, possibly Lake Fyans in the Grampians
00:23:22:00 walking along narrow pathways through the bush
00:24:14:00 sign ‘Grand Canyon’
00:25:43:00 sign ‘Echo Cave’ which appears to be painted on the rock itself
00:26:13:00 another sign ‘Pinnacle Street’ painted on a path rock
00:26:24:00 a rock worn away into the shape of a mushroom
00:26:49:00 sign ‘Silent Street’
00:28:12:00 walkers at a pinnacle lookout showing the fencing used for safety in the Grampians

00:18:23:00 climbing a steep ravine
00:20:19:00 sitting on a precipice overlooking the dramatic scenery below
00:20:43:00 a large body of water, possibly Lake Fyans in the Grampians
00:23:22:00 walking along narrow pathways through the bush
00:24:14:00 sign ‘Grand Canyon’
00:25:43:00 sign ‘Echo Cave’ which appears to be painted on the rock itself
00:26:13:00 another sign ‘Pinnacle Street’ painted on a path rock
00:26:24:00 a rock worn away into the shape of a mushroom
00:26:49:00 sign ‘Silent Street’
00:28:12:00 walkers at a pinnacle lookout showing the fencing used for safety in the Grampians
